data.title: Detect more def* forms in Clojure syntax
data.body:
It’s a convention in Clojure to use macros whose name starts with `def` to define something. Libraries often define their own custom macros for this:

- `defroutes` (Compojure)
- `defc` (Rum)
- etc

This is why whitelisting only def macros from clojure.core isn’t working: it will detect standard vars and functions but will fail to detect custom `def*`-like macros.

This PR adds regular expression that treats all forms whose name starts with `def` (with optional namespace) similarly.

This convention is very well established so it shouldn’t hurt anyone.

data.title: Global launch config conflicts with local launch.json
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.0 Insider
- OS Version: macOS

Steps to Reproduce:

Add this launch config to your user settings:
```js
	"launch": {
		"configurations": [
			{
				"type": "node",
				"request": "launch",
				"name": "Default Launch Program",
				"program": "${file}",
				"protocol": "legacy"
			}
		]
	}
```
Open a project folder with a simple program test.js containing `console.log("hello")`.

Press F5.

Observe: the program runs fine.

Now add a launch config to the project.

Press F5 again.

Observe: an error occurs "Configuration 'Default Launch Program' is missing in 'launch.json'.

This is very confusing and not helpful: 'F5' should just work with the local launch.json. The one from user settings should not be considered at all.

This issue is also typescript related.

If hovering a module it very nice if:
- If found: Found also which path is used finally - can be very helpful since the node module resolving strategy is complicated and long

data.title: Prevent VS Code from closing when no open files and pressing CTRL-W
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Is it possible to *not* close VS Code when pressing CTRL-F4 / CTRL-W and there are no open files? 

I usually have a bunch of files open, related to what I'm currently working on, and when I'm done, I just want to close them all quickly and get them out of the way and for that, I'm used to keeping CTRL-W pressed until all files are closed. With VS Code that leads to the editor being also closed after the last file is closed.

Thank you!

data.title: Clarify 'percentage' in 'withProgress'
data.body:
Testing #18066

When using vscode.window.withProgress you get a progress that lets you set message and percentage.
What wasn't clear to me, what is the value range of percentage: (0...100) or (0..1.) ?

I didn't see any indication of that percentage, the status bar just shows the spinning wheel.

data.title: JavaScript: Using division in `if` condition across multiple lines mis-reported as error
data.body:
- VSCode Version: `1.11.2`
- OS Version: `macOS 10.12.2`

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Create new JavaScript file
2. Enter the following code:
    ```
    function test(x, y) {
      if ((x / y) < 1 &&
          (x > 0)) {
        return 'a';
      }
    }
    ```
3. The following problems are reported:
    - `[js] '=' expected. (2, 10)`
    - `[js] Unterminated regular expression literal. (2, 11)`
    - `[js] '=>' expected. (3, 16)`
    - `[js] ')' expected. (6, 1)`

## Expected behaviour

The code executes correctly and doesn't appear to have any issues according to other linters and syntax validators

data.title: Javascript format breaks with bracketed function names and async (ES7) keyword
Pool already loaded VS Code instances to enable startup acceleration
data.body:
Hi all,

VS Code is my targeted replacement for all the other Editors that are either needed to be licensed or old fashioned....

What really makes me cry is the "long" loading time when launching VS Code - while "long" is relative since it is overall 3s, but constantly more than other editors.

I've found a few threads about real issues (10-30s), but I never found an approach how to reduce the time to a few milliseconds.

My current performance stats:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2744285/25474248/cde19aba-2b32-11e7-8df6-b67931e9b23a.png)

So:
- I want a really fast startup performance
- I have a hell of RAM free

Would it be possible / makes sense to preload instances of Visual Studio Code on Boot, so VS Code Instances would be pooled / preloaded?

Just as an idea....
Cheers,
µatthias

data.title: [MAC] Code Helper process using more than 1GB memory and slows down the whole system
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.2 (6eaebe3b9c70406d67c97779468c324a7a95db0e, 2017-04-13T07:56:42.517Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|crane|HvyIndustries|0.3.6|
|vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.13|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.8|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.0|
|vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.1.8|
|php-debug|felixfbecker|1.10.0|
|code-runner|formulahendry|0.6.15|
|vue|jcbuisson|0.1.5|
|vscode-apache|mrmlnc|1.1.1|
|mssql|ms-mssql|0.3.0|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.10.5|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.7.0|
|vuehelper|oysun|0.1.0|
|java|redhat|0.0.13|
|php-ci|small|0.1.3|;


---

Steps to Reproduce: (I'm not sure whether they're the exact steps leading to the issue, but i'm listing my daily routine operations here)

1. Start VS code, open my project (a website project containing php/javascripts/css)
2. Using VS code command panel to start docker compose 
3. Work on my codes 
4. Usually, after half a day, my 8GB system will become very slow and un-responsive at all, in the activity monitor, the "Code Helper" process is using more than 1GB memory. I have to kill VS code, then the whole system becomes normal again.

Next time when the issue happens, I'll try to get some reports from 'ps' command.

data.title: Add editorSuggestFocusBackground and editorSuggestForegroundColor
data.body:
The selected entry in the suggest widget uses the listFocusBackground color.
It makes sense to add a specific color for it, given that the background color can be customized.

data.title: Cannot associate a problem matcher with an auto detected tasks
data.body:
Testing #25299 

I have a gruntfile with a linter task and I'd like to attach a problem matcher with the auto detected task. I haven't found a way to do so, e.g., I cannot generate a corresponding task.json from the gruntfile since all tasks are auto detected.

data.title: Suggest to prefix the detected tasks with the task runner
data.body:
Testing #25299 

See the setup in the screenshot.

I type 'task ' into the command palette. The grunt tasks get properly detected:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/172399/25471390/2ad79852-2b27-11e7-8c77-d82c6b77ae0e.png)

I suggest to prefix the detected tasks with the task runner that detected them, e.g.
`grunt:jshint`.

This makes it more explicit where a task is coming form and helps when tasks get contributed from different task contributors (e.g. npm scripts).
